headline: Did JPMorgan’s Apple Card Reserve Build and Political Scrutiny Just Shift JPM's Investment Narrative?
summary: In recent days, JPMorgan Chase reported fourth-quarter and full-year 2025 results showing higher net interest income but slightly lower quarterly net income, while also taking a one-time US$2.20 billion reserve build tied to acquiring Goldman Sachs’ roughly US$20 billion Apple Card portfolio. At the same time, the bank is in the spotlight over a proposed 10% cap on credit card interest rates and fresh political scrutiny around alleged “debanking,” issues that are influencing how investors...

headline: JPMorgan will likely have fewer employees in 5 years, CEO Dimon says
summary: At the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, JPMorgan Chase (JPM) CEO Jamie Dimon spoke about the impact AI will have on the global workforce and what companies and governments can do to help. Toward the end of the conversation, he was asked about jobs at JPMorgan Chase, and Dimon admitted that his "guess" is that the banking giant will have fewer employees in five years than it does today. Watch Dimon's full World Economic Forum discussion.

Toward the end of the conversation, he was asked about jobs at JPMorgan Chase, and Dimon admitted that his "guess" is that the banking giant will have fewer employees in five years than it does today.

Watch Dimon's full World Economic Forum discussion.

headline: JPMorgan CEO Dimon Says Credit Card Cap Would Be 'Economic Disaster'
summary: JPMorgan CEO Jamie Dimon explains why US President Donald Trump's call for credit-card companies to cap the interest rates they charge would be an "economic disaster." He speaks during an interview with Economist Editor-in-Chief Zanny Minton Beddoes at the World Economic Forum's annual meeting in Davos, Switzerland.

content.title: JPMorgan CEO Dimon Says Credit Card Cap Would Be 'Economic Disaster'

headline: JPMorgan's Dimon on why the Fed isn't as independent as people think
summary: Federal Reserve Chair Jerome Powell says he is facing a criminal investigation by the US Department of Justice over his testimony about renovations to the Fed's headquarters in Washington DC. At the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, JPMorgan Chase (JPM) CEO Jamie Dimon says he thinks the probe is "lawfare," but he also makes the case that the central bank isn't quite as independent as people think. Watch Dimon's full World Economic Forum discussion.

content.title: JPMorgan's Dimon on why the Fed isn't as independent as people think
content.description:

At the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland, JPMorgan Chase (JPM) CEO Jamie Dimon says he thinks the probe is "lawfare," but he also makes the case that the central bank isn't quite as independent as people think.

Watch Dimon's full World Economic Forum discussion.

headline: Update: Market Chatter: JPMorgan CEO Says Trump's Proposal for 10% Credit Card Rate Cap Will Be Economic Disaster
summary: (Updates with JPMorgan CEO Jamie Dimon's comments from CNBC report starting from fourth paragraph.)

content.title: Update: Market Chatter: JPMorgan CEO Says Trump's Proposal for 10% Credit Card Rate Cap Will Be Economic Disaster
content.summary: (Updates with JPMorgan CEO Jamie Dimon's comments from CNBC report starting from fourth paragraph.)

headline: Dimon Says Credit-Card Cap Will Be an ‘Economic Disaster’
summary: JPMorgan's chief executive said a blanket 10% interest rate-cap on credit-card loans would be an “economic disaster”.  “In the worst case, you would have a drastic reduction in the credit card business,” Jamie Dimon said in Davos, Switzerland, adding that in that scenario, the people “crying the most” would not be the credit card companies but businesses including restaurants, retailers and travel companies as these entities lose their credit.  Dimon and JPMorgan have already publicly opposed the cap, but Dimon’s wording on Wednesday was harsher than what the bank’s finance chief Jeremy Barnum said—“very bad for consumers”—earlier this month.

content.title: Dimon Says Credit-Card Cap Will Be an ‘Economic Disaster’
content.summary: JPMorgan's chief executive said a blanket 10% interest rate-cap on credit-card loans would be an “economic disaster”.  “In the worst case, you would have a drastic reduction in the credit card business,” Jamie Dimon said in Davos, Switzerland, adding that in that scenario, the people “crying the most” would not be the credit card companies but businesses including restaurants, retailers and travel companies as these entities lose their credit.  Dimon and JPMorgan have already publicly opposed the cap, but Dimon’s wording on Wednesday was harsher than what the bank’s finance chief Jeremy Barnum said—“very bad for consumers”—earlier this month.

headline: JPMorgan's Dimon says credit card rate cap will be 'economic disaster'
summary:
STORY: :: Dimon says a cap on credit card interest rates would be an 'economic disaster'

:: January 21, 2026

:: Davos, Switzerland

JOURNALIST, ZANNY MINTON BEDDOES: “One of President Trump's recent proposals that would directly affect you, he's doing it to improve affordability, is to impose a 10% cap on credit card rates. Is that a bad idea?"

:: Jamie Dimon, JPMorgan CEO

“It would be an economic disaster, and I'm not making it up because our business, we would survive it by the way. In the worst case that you would have a drastic reduction of the credit card business. I mean drastic,  I (don’t)  mean, like 10%, I mean like 80%. It would remove credit from 80% of Americans, and that is their backup credit."  //  "And the people crying the most won't be the credit card companies, it would be the restaurants, the retailers, the travel companies, the schools, the municipalities..."

President Donald Trump, under pressure to address voters' cost-of-living concerns ahead of this year's congressional elections, called for the cap earlier this month, without detailing how the plan would be implemented.‌

JPMorgan and Wall Street's most influential banker, said at the World Economic Forum in Davos.

Banking industry bodies have pushed back strongly against the move, arguing it would limit credit access for everyday consumers. Meanwhile, Wall Street analysts said such a measure would require legislation and has slim odds of passage, with Democrats and Republicans divided over it.

content.title: JPMorgan's Dimon says credit card rate cap will be 'economic disaster'
content.summary:
STORY: :: Dimon says a cap on credit card interest rates would be an 'economic disaster'

:: January 21, 2026

:: Davos, Switzerland

JOURNALIST, ZANNY MINTON BEDDOES: “One of President Trump's recent proposals that would directly affect you, he's doing it to improve affordability, is to impose a 10% cap on credit card rates. Is that a bad idea?"

:: Jamie Dimon, JPMorgan CEO

“It would be an economic disaster, and I'm not making it up because our business, we would survive it by the way. In the worst case that you would have a drastic reduction of the credit card business. I mean drastic,  I (don’t)  mean, like 10%, I mean like 80%. It would remove credit from 80% of Americans, and that is their backup credit."  //  "And the people crying the most won't be the credit card companies, it would be the restaurants, the retailers, the travel companies, the schools, the municipalities..."

President Donald Trump, under pressure to address voters' cost-of-living concerns ahead of this year's congressional elections, called for the cap earlier this month, without detailing how the plan would be implemented.‌

JPMorgan and Wall Street's most influential banker, said at the World Economic Forum in Davos.

Banking industry bodies have pushed back strongly against the move, arguing it would limit credit access for everyday consumers. Meanwhile, Wall Street analysts said such a measure would require legislation and has slim odds of passage, with Democrats and Republicans divided over it.

headline: Trump Looks to Congress to Cap Credit Card Rates at 10%
summary: “I’m asking Congress to cap credit card interest rates at 10% for one year and this will help millions of Americans save for a home,” Trump said Wednesday in a speech at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland.  Earlier this month, Trump took aim at credit card interest rates, posting on social media that he would call for a one-year cap.

content.title: Trump Looks to Congress to Cap Credit Card Rates at 10%
content.summary: “I’m asking Congress to cap credit card interest rates at 10% for one year and this will help millions of Americans save for a home,” Trump said Wednesday in a speech at the World Economic Forum in Davos, Switzerland.  Earlier this month, Trump took aim at credit card interest rates, posting on social media that he would call for a one-year cap.

headline: Is JPMorgan Chase (JPM) Still Attractively Priced After Recent Share Price Pullback
summary: If you are wondering whether JPMorgan Chase is priced for its reputation or still offers room for value, it starts with understanding how the current share price lines up against the bank's fundamentals. The stock last closed at US$302.74, after a 2.6% decline over the past week and a 4.6% decline over the past month, while still showing a 17.5% return over 1 year and very large gains over 3 and 5 years. Recent coverage has focused on JPMorgan Chase's role as a major US bank and how its size...
